questions.question_text: According to Dalton's atomic theory, atoms are:

options.label: A
options.text: Divisible into subatomic particles

options.label: B
options.text: Indivisible particles

options.label: C
options.text: Created and destroyed in chemical reactions

options.label: D
options.text: Always identical in mass for an element

questions.key_concept: Dalton's postulate: Atoms are indivisible.

questions.question_text: Which postulate of Dalton's theory is still considered correct in modern atomic theory?

options.label: A
options.text: Atoms are indivisible.

options.label: B
options.text: Atoms of an element are identical in all respects.

options.label: C
options.text: Atoms take part in chemical reactions.

options.label: D
options.text: Atoms can neither be created nor destroyed.

questions.key_concept: Modern theory retains that atoms are the smallest units taking part in chemical reactions.

questions.question_text: A student claims that according to Dalton, atoms of the same element have the same mass number. Why is this statement incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Dalton said atoms of an element are alike, but modern isotopes prove they can differ in mass.

options.label: B
options.text: Dalton never mentioned mass; he only talked about size.

options.label: C
options.text: Dalton's theory applies only to gases, not solids.

options.label: D
options.text: Mass number is a concept from Bohr's model, not Dalton's.

questions.key_concept: Dalton's 'alike in all respects' is contradicted by isotopes.

questions.question_text: If two elements combine in a simple ratio to form a compound, which postulate of Dalton's theory does this illustrate?

options.label: A
options.text: Atoms are indivisible.

options.label: B
options.text: Atoms combine in small numbers to form molecules.

options.label: C
options.text: Atoms of one element combine with atoms of another in a simple ratio.

options.label: D
options.text: Atoms can neither be created nor destroyed.

questions.key_concept: Law of definite proportions is explained by Dalton's postulate on simple ratios.

questions.question_text: How does the modern atomic theory's view on the creation/destruction of atoms differ from Dalton's?

options.label: A
options.text: Modern theory says atoms can be created and destroyed only in chemical reactions.

options.label: B
options.text: Modern theory says atoms can be created and destroyed by nuclear fusion and fission, not ordinary chemical reactions.

options.label: C
options.text: Modern theory fully agrees with Dalton that atoms are indestructible.

options.label: D
options.text: Modern theory says atoms are destroyed by radioactivity but not created.

questions.key_concept: Nuclear processes can create/destroy atoms, unlike ordinary chemical reactions.

questions.question_text: Why did Dalton's atomic theory successfully explain the laws of chemical combination at the time?

options.label: A
options.text: It introduced the concept of subatomic particles, which allowed for ratio calculations.

options.label: B
options.text: It proposed that atoms combine in fixed, simple ratios, aligning with observed constant composition in compounds.

options.label: C
options.text: It accounted for the existence of isotopes, which affect combining masses.

options.label: D
options.text: It explained electrical conductivity in compounds, crucial for combination studies.

questions.key_concept: Dalton's theory provided a particulate basis for the laws of constant composition and multiple proportions.

questions.question_text: What are cathode rays?

options.label: A
options.text: Streams of positively charged particles originating from the anode.

options.label: B
options.text: Streams of negatively charged particles originating from the cathode.

options.label: C
options.text: Neutral radiation produced when X-rays hit a metal.

options.label: D
options.text: Visible light emitted by heated cathodes.

questions.key_concept: Cathode rays are streams of electrons from the cathode.

questions.question_text: Who is credited with the discovery of the electron as a subatomic particle?

options.label: A
options.text: E. Goldstein

options.label: B
options.text: J.J. Thomson

options.label: C
options.text: James Chadwick

options.label: D
options.text: Lord Rutherford

questions.key_concept: J.J. Thomson studied cathode rays and identified the electron.

questions.question_text: A student states that the charge-to-mass ratio (e/m) of cathode rays depends on the gas in the discharge tube. Why is this wrong?

options.label: A
options.text: e/m depends on the metal of the cathode, not the gas.

options.label: B
options.text: e/m is constant for cathode rays regardless of the gas or cathode material, proving electrons are universal.

options.label: C
options.text: e/m varies only for anode rays, not cathode rays.

options.label: D
options.text: Cathode rays do not have a measurable e/m ratio.

questions.key_concept: Constant e/m for cathode rays was key evidence for electrons as a fundamental particle.

questions.question_text: Which property of cathode rays is utilized in the production of X-rays?

options.label: A
options.text: Their ability to cause fluorescence.

options.label: B
options.text: Their deflection by electric fields.

options.label: C
options.text: Their penetration through matter.

options.label: D
options.text: Their production when striking a hard metallic target like tungsten.

questions.key_concept: Cathode rays produce X-rays upon striking a metal target.

questions.question_text: How do the properties of electrons differ from those of protons in terms of charge and mass?

options.label: A
options.text: Electrons and protons have equal but opposite charges, and protons are slightly lighter.

options.label: B
options.text: Electrons have a negative charge and negligible mass compared to protons, which have a positive charge and significant mass.

options.label: C
options.text: Electrons have a positive charge and mass equal to protons.

options.label: D
options.text: Electrons have no charge but have mass similar to neutrons.

questions.key_concept: Electron: negative, mass ~1/1837 of H atom. Proton: positive, mass ~1 amu.

questions.question_text: Why does the deflection of cathode rays in an electric field towards the positive plate prove they are negatively charged?

options.label: A
options.text: Like charges attract, so negative rays are attracted to the positive plate.

options.label: B
options.text: Opposite charges repel, so they are pushed away from the negative plate.

options.label: C
options.text: The electric field accelerates all particles equally, regardless of charge.

options.label: D
options.text: The deflection is due to their mass, not their charge.

questions.key_concept: Oppositely charged objects attract. Negative cathode rays are attracted to the positive plate.

questions.question_text: What are anode rays?

options.label: A
options.text: Rays of light emitted by the anode when heated.

options.label: B
options.text: Streams of positively charged particles originating from the anode or passing through a perforated cathode.

options.label: C
options.text: Neutral particles discovered by Chadwick.

options.label: D
options.text: Another name for cathode rays.

questions.key_concept: Anode rays are positive rays, discovered by Goldstein.

questions.question_text: Who discovered the proton?

options.label: A
options.text: J.J. Thomson

options.label: B
options.text: E. Goldstein

options.label: C
options.text: John Dalton

options.label: D
options.text: Niels Bohr

questions.key_concept: Goldstein discovered protons (positive rays) in discharge tube experiments.

questions.question_text: A student says the charge-to-mass ratio (e/m) for anode rays is constant, like for cathode rays. Why is this incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Anode rays have no charge, so e/m is zero.

options.label: B
options.text: e/m for anode rays varies with the gas used, as they are positive ions of different masses.

options.label: C
options.text: e/m for anode rays is constant but much higher than for electrons.

options.label: D
options.text: Anode rays are not deflected by fields, so e/m cannot be measured.

questions.key_concept: Anode rays are positive ions; their e/m depends on the ion's mass, which varies with the gas.

questions.question_text: How is a proton formed from a hydrogen atom?

options.label: A
options.text: By gaining an electron.

options.label: B
options.text: By losing its neutron.

options.label: C
options.text: By losing its single electron.

options.label: D
options.text: By fusing with another hydrogen atom.

questions.key_concept: H atom (1p, 1e) loses 1 electron to become H+ (a proton).

questions.question_text: How do the deflection directions of cathode rays and anode rays in an electric field compare?

options.label: A
options.text: Both deflect towards the positive plate.

options.label: B
options.text: Cathode rays deflect towards the positive plate; anode rays deflect towards the negative plate.

options.label: C
options.text: Both deflect towards the negative plate.

options.label: D
options.text: Cathode rays are not deflected, only anode rays are.

questions.key_concept: Opposite charges deflect in opposite directions in the same field.

questions.question_text: Why was the discovery of the proton necessary to explain the neutrality of the atom?

options.label: A
options.text: Atoms were known to be neutral, and electrons provided negative charge, so an equal positive charge was needed.

options.label: B
options.text: Protons were needed to account for the atom's volume, as electrons were too small.

options.label: C
options.text: Protons explained radioactivity, which electrons could not.

options.label: D
options.text: Protons were discovered before electrons, so they defined neutrality.

questions.key_concept: Neutral atom requires balancing negative electron charge with positive proton charge.

questions.question_text: What was J.J. Thomson's model of the atom often called?

options.label: A
options.text: Nuclear model

options.label: B
options.text: Planetary model

options.label: C
options.text: Plum pudding model

options.label: D
options.text: Bohr's model

questions.key_concept: Thomson's model: electrons embedded in a uniform positive sphere.

questions.question_text: According to Thomson's model, how is the atom's positive charge distributed?

options.label: A
options.text: Concentrated in a tiny nucleus.

options.label: B
options.text: Uniformly spread throughout the atom.

options.label: C
options.text: Located in shells outside the nucleus.

options.label: D
options.text: Carried only by protons in fixed orbits.

questions.key_concept: Thomson's model: sphere of uniform positive charge.

questions.question_text: A student suggests that in Thomson's model, electrons are stationary at fixed points. Why is this a misconception?

options.label: A
options.text: Thomson specifically stated electrons orbited the nucleus.

options.label: B
options.text: The model depicted electrons as embedded and possibly moving, but not in specific orbits; it was a diffuse cloud.

options.label: C
options.text: Electrons were outside the positive sphere, not embedded.

options.label: D
options.text: Thomson's model had no electrons at all.

questions.key_concept: Plum pudding model had electrons within the positive matrix, not in defined orbits.

questions.question_text: How did Thomson's model explain the overall electrical neutrality of an atom?

options.label: A
options.text: By having an equal number of protons and neutrons in the nucleus.

options.label: B
options.text: By having the total positive charge of the sphere equal to the total negative charge of the embedded electrons.

options.label: C
options.text: By having electrons with no charge.

options.label: D
options.text: By having the positive and negative charges cancel in each electron.

questions.key_concept: Neutrality achieved by balancing charges.

questions.question_text: How does Thomson's model differ fundamentally from Rutherford's model regarding mass distribution?

options.label: A
options.text: Thomson: mass uniformly distributed. Rutherford: mass concentrated in a nucleus.

options.label: B
options.text: Thomson: mass in electrons. Rutherford: mass in protons only.

options.label: C
options.text: Both models have mass uniformly distributed.

options.label: D
options.text: Thomson: mass in nucleus. Rutherford: mass in orbits.

questions.key_concept: Key difference: uniform vs. concentrated mass.

questions.question_text: Why was Thomson's model eventually rejected?

options.label: A
options.text: It could not explain the emission spectra of elements.

options.label: B
options.text: It could not explain the results of Rutherford's alpha scattering experiment (most alpha particles passed through, but some were deflected sharply).

options.label: C
options.text: It predicted atoms should be unstable, which they are not.

options.label: D
options.text: It did not account for the existence of neutrons.

questions.key_concept: Rutherford's experiment showed a concentrated positive charge, contradicting the diffuse positive sphere.

questions.question_text: What is an alpha particle?

options.label: A
options.text: A high-energy electron.

options.label: B
options.text: A doubly charged helium ion (He²⁺).

options.label: C
options.text: A neutral particle discovered by Chadwick.

options.label: D
options.text: A positively charged hydrogen ion.

questions.key_concept: Alpha particle: He nucleus (2p, 2n), charge +2.

questions.question_text: What was the key observation in Rutherford's experiment that suggested the atom had a dense, positive core?

options.label: A
options.text: Most alpha particles passed straight through the foil.

options.label: B
options.text: A few alpha particles were deflected by very large angles, some even bouncing back.

options.label: C
options.text: All alpha particles were absorbed by the foil.

options.label: D
options.text: Alpha particles caused the foil to emit light.

questions.key_concept: Large-angle deflection indicated a concentrated positive charge (nucleus).

questions.question_text: A student thinks that if a light nucleus like lithium is used in the alpha scattering experiment, most alpha particles would bounce back. Why is this incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Alpha particles are negatively charged and would be repelled by lithium.

options.label: B
options.text: Light nuclei have less mass/charge; alpha particles may push them aside and not be deflected back significantly.

options.label: C
options.text: Lithium is non-metallic, so it doesn't scatter alpha particles.

options.label: D
options.text: Alpha particles cannot penetrate lithium foil.

questions.key_concept: Heavy nuclei (like gold) cause large deflections; light nuclei may not.

questions.question_text: Why did Rutherford choose a gold foil for his experiment?

options.label: A
options.text: Gold is a good conductor of electricity.

options.label: B
options.text: Gold is the most malleable metal, allowing a very thin foil to be made.

options.label: C
options.text: Gold has the highest atomic number, making deflection easier to observe.

options.label: D
options.text: Gold does not react with alpha particles.

questions.key_concept: Thin foil minimizes multiple scattering events, making observations clearer.

questions.question_text: How do the observations 'most alpha particles passed straight' and 'very few were deflected back' together lead to conclusions about the atom?

options.label: A
options.text: Straight pass: atom is mostly solid. Deflected back: electrons are heavy.

options.label: B
options.text: Straight pass: atom is mostly empty space. Deflected back: positive charge and mass are concentrated in a tiny nucleus.

options.label: C
options.text: Straight pass: nucleus is large. Deflected back: electrons are in fixed orbits.

options.label: D
options.text: Both observations prove the plum pudding model correct.

questions.key_concept: Combined observations led to the nuclear model.

questions.question_text: Why couldn't the large-angle deflections of alpha particles be explained by collisions with electrons?

options.label: A
options.text: Electrons are positively charged and would attract alpha particles.

options.label: B
options.text: Electrons have negligible mass compared to alpha particles; they cannot cause significant deflection.

options.label: C
options.text: Electrons are located in the nucleus, not in the path of alpha particles.

options.label: D
options.text: Alpha particles and electrons have the same charge, so they repel.

questions.key_concept: Deflection requires interaction with a massive, similarly charged object (nucleus).

concepts.concept_name: Rutherford's Nuclear Model of the Atom

questions.question_text: According to Rutherford's model, where is most of the mass of an atom concentrated?

options.label: A
options.text: In the electrons orbiting the nucleus.

options.label: B
options.text: Uniformly throughout the atom.

options.label: C
options.text: In the nucleus at the centre.

options.label: D
options.text: In the empty space between the nucleus and electrons.

questions.key_concept: Mass is concentrated in the nucleus.

questions.question_text: What did Rutherford name the central, positively charged part of the atom?

options.label: A
options.text: Orbit

options.label: B
options.text: Proton

options.label: C
options.text: Nucleus

options.label: D
options.text: Neutron

questions.key_concept: Rutherford discovered and named the nucleus.

questions.question_text: A student says that in Rutherford's model, electrons are stationary around the nucleus. What is the error?

options.label: A
options.text: Electrons were said to revolve in orbits, not be stationary.

options.label: B
options.text: Electrons were inside the nucleus.

options.label: C
options.text: Rutherford's model did not include electrons.

options.label: D
options.text: Electrons were vibrating, not revolving.

questions.key_concept: Rutherford proposed electrons revolve around the nucleus.

questions.question_text: How does Rutherford's model explain the electrical neutrality of an atom?

options.label: A
options.text: The positive charge of the protons in the nucleus is balanced by the negative charge of the electrons in orbits.

options.label: B
options.text: The nucleus contains equal protons and neutrons, making it neutral.

options.label: C
options.text: Electrons have no charge.

options.label: D
options.text: The empty space has a neutralizing effect.

questions.key_concept: Neutrality: number of protons = number of electrons.

questions.question_text: How is Rutherford's model similar to the solar system?

options.label: A
options.text: Both have a central, massive body (sun/nucleus) around which lighter bodies (planets/electrons) revolve.

options.label: B
options.text: Both have bodies of equal mass orbiting each other.

options.label: C
options.text: In both, the central body has a negative charge.

options.label: D
options.text: Both systems are held by gravitational force only.

questions.key_concept: Analogy: sun/nucleus (massive), planets/electrons (revolving).

questions.question_text: What was the major drawback of Rutherford's model regarding atomic stability?

options.label: A
options.text: It could not explain the existence of isotopes.

options.label: B
options.text: According to classical physics, a revolving electron should continuously lose energy and spiral into the nucleus, collapsing the atom.

options.label: C
options.text: It predicted atoms should be negatively charged.

options.label: D
options.text: It did not account for the neutron, so mass calculations were wrong.

questions.key_concept: Revolving charged particle radiates energy, leading to instability. Bohr solved this.

questions.question_text: What are the fixed paths called in which electrons revolve according to Bohr's model?

options.label: A
options.text: Nuclei

options.label: B
options.text: Orbits, shells, or energy levels

options.label: C
options.text: Clouds

options.label: D
options.text: Waves

questions.key_concept: Bohr introduced stationary orbits/energy levels.

questions.question_text: According to Bohr's postulate, what happens to the energy of an electron while it is in a particular orbit?

options.label: A
options.text: It continuously increases.

options.label: B
options.text: It continuously decreases due to radiation.

options.label: C
options.text: It neither loses nor gains energy.

options.label: D
options.text: It fluctuates randomly.

questions.key_concept: Electrons in stationary orbits do not radiate energy.

questions.question_text: A student thinks that in Bohr's model, an electron can exist anywhere between two orbits. Why is this incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Electrons can only exist in the nucleus or in orbits, not between.

options.label: B
options.text: Electrons exist in specific, quantized orbits with fixed energies; they cannot exist in between.

options.label: C
options.text: Electrons form a cloud between orbits according to Bohr.

options.label: D
options.text: Bohr's model allows electrons to move freely in the empty space.

questions.key_concept: Energy levels are quantized; electrons jump between them, not exist in between.

questions.question_text: How does Bohr's model explain the stability of the atom?

options.label: A
options.text: By proposing that electrons do not radiate energy while in their fixed orbits.

options.label: B
options.text: By introducing neutrons in the nucleus to provide strong force.

options.label: C
options.text: By making the nucleus very small.

options.label: D
options.text: By having electrons move at constant speed.

questions.key_concept: Fixed orbits without energy loss prevent collapse into nucleus.

questions.question_text: How did Bohr's model improve upon Rutherford's model?

options.label: A
options.text: It introduced the nucleus.

options.label: B
options.text: It introduced the concept of stationary orbits to explain atomic stability and discrete energy levels.

options.label: C
options.text: It discovered the proton.

options.label: D
options.text: It explained the existence of isotopes.

questions.key_concept: Bohr added quantization to solve the stability issue of Rutherford's model.

questions.question_text: Why is the orbit closest to the nucleus (K-shell) said to have the least energy?

options.label: A
options.text: Electrons there move the slowest, so they have low kinetic energy.

options.label: B
options.text: It requires the most energy to remove an electron from that shell due to strong nuclear attraction.

options.label: C
options.text: The electron is most strongly bound to the nucleus; it has the lowest (most negative) potential energy.

options.label: D
options.text: The nucleus shares its energy with the K-shell electrons.

questions.key_concept: Lower orbits have lower (more negative) energy; more energy is needed to remove the electron (ionize).

questions.question_text: What is a neutron?

options.label: A
options.text: A positively charged subatomic particle.

options.label: B
options.text: A negatively charged subatomic particle.

options.label: C
options.text: A neutral subatomic particle with mass nearly equal to a proton.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of electron found in the nucleus.

questions.key_concept: Neutron: neutral, mass ~1 amu, in nucleus.

questions.question_text: Who discovered the neutron?

options.label: A
options.text: J.J. Thomson

options.label: B
options.text: E. Goldstein

options.label: C
options.text: James Chadwick

options.label: D
options.text: Niels Bohr

questions.key_concept: Chadwick discovered the neutron in 1932.

questions.question_text: A student states that neutrons are deflected by electric fields. Why is this incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Neutrons have a small positive charge, but the deflection is too small to observe.

options.label: B
options.text: Neutrons are electrically neutral, so they are not affected by electric fields.

options.label: C
options.text: Neutrons are too heavy to be deflected.

options.label: D
options.text: Electric fields only affect particles inside the nucleus.

questions.key_concept: No charge means no force in an electric field.

questions.question_text: Why was the discovery of the neutron necessary to explain the atomic mass of elements?

options.label: A
options.text: Protons and electrons could not account for the total mass; neutrons provided the extra mass.

options.label: B
options.text: Neutrons were needed to balance the charge in the nucleus.

options.label: C
options.text: Electrons were found to have significant mass, so neutrons were not needed.

options.label: D
options.text: Neutrons explained chemical bonding, which affects mass.

questions.key_concept: e.g., Helium: 2 protons give mass ~2 amu, but actual ~4 amu. Neutrons account for the difference.

questions.question_text: How do protons and neutrons compare in terms of charge and approximate mass?

options.label: A
options.text: Both have the same charge but different masses.

options.label: B
options.text: Proton: positive charge, mass ~1 amu. Neutron: no charge, mass slightly greater than proton.

options.label: C
options.text: Proton: no charge, mass 1 amu. Neutron: negative charge, mass 1 amu.

options.label: D
options.text: Both are neutral, but neutrons are much lighter.

questions.key_concept: Proton: +1, ~1 amu. Neutron: 0, ~1.008 amu (slightly heavier).

questions.question_text: In the equation for neutron discovery: Be⁹ + He⁴ → C¹² + n¹, why is the product particle (n¹) identified as a neutron?

options.label: A
options.text: It had a positive charge and mass of 1 amu.

options.label: B
options.text: It was not deflected by electric/magnetic fields (neutral) and had mass roughly equal to a proton.

options.label: C
options.text: It caused fluorescence like cathode rays.

options.label: D
options.text: It was attracted to the cathode in a discharge tube.

questions.key_concept: Neutrality and mass were key identifying properties.

questions.question_text: What is the atomic number (Z) of an element?

options.label: A
options.text: The total number of protons and neutrons in its atom.

options.label: B
options.text: The number of protons in the nucleus of its atom.

options.label: C
options.text: The number of electrons in the outermost shell.

options.label: D
options.text: The total number of nucleons.

questions.key_concept: Atomic number = number of protons.

questions.question_text: In a neutral atom, what is the relationship between atomic number (Z) and the number of electrons?

options.label: A
options.text: Z is always greater than the number of electrons.

options.label: B
options.text: Z is equal to the number of electrons.

options.label: C
options.text: Z is always less than the number of electrons.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no fixed relationship.

questions.key_concept: In a neutral atom, protons = electrons, so Z = number of electrons.

questions.question_text: A student calculates the mass number of an atom as the sum of protons and electrons. What is the error?

options.label: A
options.text: Mass number is protons + neutrons; electron mass is negligible.

options.label: B
options.text: Mass number is protons only.

options.label: C
options.text: Electrons have significant mass and must be included.

options.label: D
options.text: Mass number is neutrons + electrons.

questions.key_concept: Mass number (A) = number of protons (Z) + number of neutrons (N).

questions.question_text: An element has atomic number 11 and mass number 23. How many neutrons does it have?
questions.key_concept: Number of neutrons = A - Z = 23 - 11 = 12.

questions.question_text: How do atomic number (Z) and mass number (A) differ in terms of the information they provide about an atom?

options.label: A
options.text: Z identifies the element and its chemical properties; A gives the approximate mass and helps identify isotopes.

options.label: B
options.text: Z gives the mass; A gives the charge.

options.label: C
options.text: Both Z and A identify the element uniquely.

options.label: D
options.text: Z is the number of shells; A is the number of electrons.

questions.key_concept: Z defines the element; A gives mass and helps distinguish isotopes.

questions.question_text: Why is the atomic number considered a more fundamental property of an element than its mass number?

options.label: A
options.text: It is always a whole number, while mass number can be fractional.

options.label: B
options.text: It determines the number of electrons and thus the chemical behavior; isotopes (same Z, different A) have similar chemistry.

options.label: C
options.text: It is easier to measure experimentally.

options.label: D
options.text: It was discovered before the mass number.

questions.key_concept: Chemical properties depend on electron configuration, which is determined by Z.

questions.question_text: What does the 2n² rule determine?

options.label: A
options.text: The valency of an element.

options.label: B
options.text: The maximum number of electrons that can occupy a given shell (n).

options.label: C
options.text: The atomic mass of an element.

options.label: D
options.text: The number of protons in the nucleus.

questions.key_concept: Maximum electrons in a shell = 2n².

questions.question_text: What is the maximum number of electrons that can be present in the L-shell (n=2)?
questions.key_concept: L-shell (n=2): 2*(2)² = 8 electrons maximum.

questions.question_text: A student writes the electronic configuration of calcium (Z=20) as 2,8,10, thinking the M-shell can hold up to 18 electrons. What rule is being violated?

options.label: A
options.text: The 2n² rule is being followed correctly.

options.label: B
options.text: The rule that the outermost shell cannot have more than 8 electrons for stability (octet rule) is violated.

options.label: C
options.text: The duplet rule for the first shell is violated.

options.label: D
options.text: The rule that shells must be filled in numerical order is wrong.

questions.key_concept: For stability, the outermost shell (when not the only shell) is filled only up to 8 electrons before starting the next shell.

questions.question_text: What is the electronic configuration of an element with atomic number 17?
questions.key_concept: Chlorine (Z=17): K=2, L=8, M=7.

questions.question_text: How does the filling of electrons in shells for elements lighter than argon differ from those heavier than argon?

options.label: A
options.text: For lighter elements, inner shells are completely filled before outer shells. For heavier elements, outer shells may start filling before inner shells are full.

options.label: B
options.text: For lighter elements (up to Ar), inner shells are completely filled stepwise. For heavier ones, the next shell may start after 8 electrons in the previous shell, even if it can hold more.

options.label: C
options.text: There is no difference; the 2n² rule applies uniformly.

options.label: D
options.text: Lighter elements follow the duplet rule; heavier ones follow the octet rule.

questions.key_concept: Example: Potassium (Z=19) is 2,8,8,1, not 2,8,9, because M-shell stops at 8 before N-shell starts.

questions.question_text: Why is the outermost shell of a stable atom (except helium) limited to 8 electrons, even if the 2n² rule allows more?

options.label: A
options.text: Because 8 is the maximum number of orbits in a shell.

options.label: B
options.text: Because atoms with 8 valence electrons have the stable configuration of noble gases (octet), which is energetically favorable.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the nucleus cannot hold more than 8 electrons in the outer shell.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a limitation of Bohr's model only.

questions.key_concept: Octet rule: Atoms tend to achieve 8 electrons in the outermost shell for stability.

questions.question_text: What are valence electrons?

options.label: A
options.text: Electrons in the innermost shell.

options.label: B
options.text: Electrons present in the outermost shell of an atom.

options.label: C
options.text: All electrons present in an atom.

options.label: D
options.text: Electrons that have been lost by an atom.

questions.key_concept: Valence electrons are in the outermost shell.

questions.question_text: How many valence electrons does a magnesium atom (atomic number 12) have?
questions.key_concept: Mg config: 2,8,2. Valence electrons = 2.

questions.question_text: A student says that elements with 4 valence electrons are always metals. Why is this incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Elements with 4 valence electrons are non-metals (like Carbon, Silicon) and can be metalloids, not typical metals.

options.label: B
options.text: All elements with 4 valence electrons are inert gases.

options.label: C
options.text: Valence electrons have no relation to metallic character.

options.label: D
options.text: Metals always have 1, 2, or 3 valence electrons, without exception.

questions.key_concept: Metals typically have 1-3 valence electrons. 4 valence electrons is characteristic of Group 14 (Carbon group), which includes non-metals and metalloids.

questions.question_text: An element X has the electronic configuration 2,8,18,8,1. What type of ion will it form and what will be its charge?

options.label: A
options.text: Anion, charge -1

options.label: B
options.text: Cation, charge +1

options.label: C
options.text: Cation, charge +2

options.label: D
options.text: It will not form an ion.

questions.key_concept: 1 valence electron (metal) tends to lose it to form a +1 cation.

questions.question_text: How do metals and non-metals generally differ in terms of their valence electrons and the type of ions they form?

options.label: A
options.text: Metals: 1-3 valence electrons, lose electrons to form cations. Non-metals: 4-7 valence electrons, gain electrons to form anions.

options.label: B
options.text: Metals: 4-7 valence electrons, gain electrons. Non-metals: 1-3 valence electrons, lose electrons.

options.label: C
options.text: Both metals and non-metals lose electrons to form cations.

options.label: D
options.text: Metals form anions; non-metals form cations.

questions.key_concept: Metals are electropositive (lose e-); non-metals are electronegative (gain e-).

questions.question_text: Why do elements with the same number of valence electrons show similar chemical properties?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they have the same atomic mass.

options.label: B
options.text: Because chemical reactions involve valence electrons; similar valence electron configuration leads to similar bonding behavior.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they belong to the same period in the periodic table.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they have the same number of electron shells.

questions.key_concept: Valence electrons determine bonding and reactivity.

questions.question_text: What is the octet rule?

options.label: A
options.text: Atoms tend to have 8 protons in the nucleus.

options.label: B
options.text: Atoms tend to gain, lose, or share electrons to achieve 8 electrons in their outermost shell.

options.label: C
options.text: Atoms always have 8 neutrons.

options.label: D
options.text: The maximum number of electrons in any shell is 8.

questions.key_concept: Octet rule: Atoms achieve stable noble gas configuration (8 valence e-).

questions.question_text: Which of the following elements has an atom that naturally satisfies the octet rule?

options.label: A
options.text: Sodium (Na)

options.label: B
options.text: Chlorine (Cl)

options.label: C
options.text: Neon (Ne)

options.label: D
options.text: Oxygen (O)

questions.key_concept: Noble gases have stable octet (or duplet for He) and are inert.

questions.question_text: A student says hydrogen follows the octet rule. What is the correct principle for hydrogen?

options.label: A
options.text: Hydrogen follows the octet rule by gaining 7 electrons.

options.label: B
options.text: Hydrogen follows the duplet rule; it tends to achieve 2 electrons in its valence shell like helium.

options.label: C
options.text: Hydrogen does not follow any stability rule.

options.label: D
options.text: Hydrogen loses its electron to achieve zero electrons, like noble gases.

questions.key_concept: H has only K-shell (max 2 e-), so it aims for a duplet.

questions.question_text: Why is a sodium atom (2,8,1) chemically active?

options.label: A
options.text: It has an incomplete octet in its outermost shell.

options.label: B
options.text: It has a complete octet.

options.label: C
options.text: It has too many protons.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no neutrons.

questions.key_concept: Atoms are active if they do not have a stable octet/duplet.

questions.question_text: How does the octet rule explain the inertness of noble gases compared to the reactivity of other elements?

options.label: A
options.text: Noble gases already have a stable octet (or duplet for He), so they have no tendency to gain, lose, or share electrons. Other elements have incomplete octets and tend to react to achieve it.

options.label: B
options.text: Noble gases have no electrons, so they cannot react.

options.label: C
options.text: Noble gases have variable valence electrons, making them unstable.

options.label: D
options.text: Other elements have complete octets, making them too stable to react.

questions.key_concept: Stable configuration leads to chemical inertness.

questions.question_text: According to the octet theory, why do atoms combine?

options.label: A
options.text: To increase their mass.

options.label: B
options.text: To attain a stable electronic configuration (octet/duplet) of the nearest noble gas by gaining, losing, or sharing electrons.

options.label: C
options.text: To become electrically charged.

options.label: D
options.text: To release neutrons.

questions.key_concept: Chemical bonding is driven by the tendency to achieve stability.

questions.question_text: What are isotopes?

options.label: A
options.text: Atoms of different elements with the same mass number.

options.label: B
options.text: Atoms of the same element with the same atomic number but different mass numbers.

options.label: C
options.text: Atoms with the same number of neutrons but different protons.

options.label: D
options.text: Atoms that have lost or gained electrons.

questions.key_concept: Isotopes: same Z, different A (due to different neutrons).

questions.question_text: Which of the following pairs are isotopes?

options.label: A
options.text: ¹⁷Cl₃₅ and ¹⁷Cl₃₇

options.label: B
options.text: ¹⁸Ar₄₀ and ²₀Ca₄₀

options.label: C
options.text: ¹H₁ and ²He₄

options.label: D
options.text: ⁶C₁₂ and ⁷N₁₄

questions.key_concept: Same element (Cl), same atomic number (17), different mass numbers (35, 37).

questions.question_text: A student says that isotopes of an element have different chemical properties. Why is this incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Chemical properties depend on atomic number and electron configuration, which are the same for isotopes.

options.label: B
options.text: Isotopes have different proton numbers, causing different chemistry.

options.label: C
options.text: Isotopes are different elements altogether.

options.label: D
options.text: Only radioactive isotopes have the same chemical properties.

questions.key_concept: Isotopes have same electronic configuration, hence similar chemical properties.

questions.question_text: Chlorine has two isotopes: Cl-35 (75%) and Cl-37 (25%). What is the average atomic mass of chlorine?
How do isotopes differ from isobars?

options.label: A
options.text: Isotopes: same element (same Z), different A. Isobars: different elements (different Z), same A.

options.label: B
options.text: Isotopes: different Z, same A. Isobars: same Z, different A.

options.label: C
options.text: Both are atoms of the same element.

options.label: D
options.text: Isotopes have same neutrons, isobars have same protons.

questions.key_concept: Isotopes vs. Isobars based on Z and A.

questions.question_text: Why do isotopes have different physical properties like density and boiling point?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they have different numbers of protons, affecting nuclear charge.

options.label: B
options.text: Because physical properties often depend on mass, and isotopes have different masses due to different neutron numbers.

options.label: C
options.text: Because their electron clouds are shaped differently.

options.label: D
options.text: Because only radioactive isotopes have different physical properties.

questions.key_concept: Mass affects properties like density, diffusion rate, boiling/melting points.

questions.question_text: What is an electrovalent (ionic) bond?

options.label: A
options.text: A bond formed by the mutual sharing of electrons.

options.label: B
options.text: A bond formed by the complete transfer of electrons from one atom to another, resulting in electrostatic attraction between ions.

options.label: C
options.text: A bond between two non-metal atoms.

options.label: D
options.text: A bond within a metal lattice.

questions.key_concept: Ionic bond: transfer of electron(s), attraction between cation and anion.

questions.question_text: Which pair of elements is most likely to form an ionic compound?

options.label: A
options.text: Carbon and oxygen

options.label: B
options.text: Sodium and chlorine

options.label: C
options.text: Hydrogen and chlorine

options.label: D
options.text: Nitrogen and hydrogen

questions.key_concept: Metal (Na) and non-metal (Cl) typically form ionic bonds.

questions.question_text: A student thinks that ionic bonds can form between two non-metal atoms if one is very electronegative. Why is this generally not true for typical ionic bonding?

options.label: A
options.text: Ionic bonds require complete electron transfer, which typically happens from a metal (low IE) to a non-metal (high EA), not between two non-metals.

options.label: B
options.text: Non-metals cannot accept electrons.

options.label: C
options.text: All bonds between non-metals are ionic.

options.label: D
options.text: Electronegativity has no role in bonding.

questions.key_concept: Ionic bonding is characteristic of metal + non-metal combination.

questions.question_text: What is the electrovalency of magnesium in MgCl₂?
questions.key_concept: Mg loses 2 electrons to form Mg²⁺, so its electrovalency is 2.

questions.question_text: How does the formation of an ionic bond involve both oxidation and reduction?

options.label: A
options.text: The metal atom loses electrons (oxidation) and the non-metal atom gains those electrons (reduction); it's a redox process.

options.label: B
options.text: Both atoms undergo reduction.

options.label: C
options.text: The metal atom is reduced, and the non-metal is oxidized.

options.label: D
options.text: Ionic bond formation does not involve electron transfer, so no redox.

questions.key_concept: Electron loss = oxidation; electron gain = reduction. Simultaneous in ionic bond formation.

questions.question_text: Why are ionic compounds stable despite the repulsion between like-charged ions?

options.label: A
options.text: The repulsive forces are stronger than the attractive forces.

options.label: B
options.text: The electrostatic force of attraction between oppositely charged ions is much stronger and overcomes the repulsion between like charges.

options.label: C
options.text: Neutrons in the nucleus neutralize the repulsion.

options.label: D
options.text: Ionic compounds are not stable; they decompose easily.

questions.key_concept: Net Coulombic attraction leads to a stable lattice.

concepts.concept_name: Formation of Specific Ionic Compounds (NaCl, MgCl₂, CaO)

questions.question_text: In the formation of NaCl, which atom becomes the cation and which becomes the anion?

options.label: A
options.text: Na becomes anion (Na⁻), Cl becomes cation (Cl⁺).

options.label: B
options.text: Na becomes cation (Na⁺), Cl becomes anion (Cl⁻).

options.label: C
options.text: Both become cations.

options.label: D
options.text: Both become anions.

questions.key_concept: Metal loses e- → cation; non-metal gains e- → anion.

questions.question_text: What noble gas configurations do Na⁺ and Cl⁻ ions attain in NaCl?

options.label: A
options.text: Na⁺ attains Ne config (2,8); Cl⁻ attains Ar config (2,8,8).

options.label: B
options.text: Na⁺ attains Ar config; Cl⁻ attains Ne config.

options.label: C
options.text: Both attain He config.

options.label: D
options.text: Neither attains a noble gas config.

questions.key_concept: Ions achieve stable octet of nearest noble gas.

questions.question_text: A student writes the formula of magnesium chloride as MgCl, thinking magnesium needs to lose only one electron. What is the mistake?

options.label: A
options.text: Magnesium has 2 valence electrons; it loses both to achieve stable octet, requiring two chlorine atoms to accept them, hence MgCl₂.

options.label: B
options.text: Magnesium gains one electron from chlorine.

options.label: C
options.text: Chlorine can accept two electrons.

options.label: D
options.text: The formula MgCl is correct.

questions.key_concept: Valency of Mg is 2, Cl is 1, so formula is MgCl₂.

questions.question_text: In the formation of CaO, how many electrons are transferred per calcium atom?
questions.key_concept: Ca (2,8,8,2) loses 2 e- to form Ca²⁺; O gains 2 e- to form O²⁻.

questions.question_text: How does the ratio of ions in MgCl₂ differ from that in CaO?

options.label: A
options.text: MgCl₂ has a 1:2 ratio of metal to non-metal ions; CaO has a 1:1 ratio.

options.label: B
options.text: Both have a 1:1 ratio.

options.label: C
options.text: MgCl₂ has 1:1; CaO has 1:2.

options.label: D
options.text: Both have a 1:2 ratio.

questions.key_concept: Ratio depends on the valency of combining atoms.

questions.question_text: Why is the formula of calcium oxide CaO and not Ca₂O?

options.label: A
options.text: Calcium has valency 2, oxygen has valency 2; they combine in a 1:1 ratio to balance charges.

options.label: B
options.text: Calcium can only lose one electron.

options.label: C
options.text: Oxygen needs only one electron to form O⁻.

options.label: D
options.text: Ca₂O would have an unbalanced charge.

questions.key_concept: Charge balance: Ca²⁺ and O²⁻ combine in 1:1 ratio.

questions.question_text: What is a covalent bond?

options.label: A
options.text: A bond formed by the transfer of electrons.

options.label: B
options.text: A bond formed by the mutual sharing of one or more pairs of electrons between atoms.

options.label: C
options.text: A bond between a metal and a non-metal.

options.label: D
options.text: A bond that exists only in gases.

questions.key_concept: Covalent bond: sharing of electron pairs.

questions.question_text: Which molecule contains a triple covalent bond?

options.label: A
options.text: H₂

options.label: B
options.text: O₂

options.label: C
options.text: N₂

options.label: D
options.text: Cl₂

questions.key_concept: Nitrogen molecule (N≡N) has a triple bond.

questions.question_text: A student says that covalent bonds can only form between identical atoms. Why is this incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Covalent bonds form between non-metal atoms, which can be different (e.g., H₂O, NH₃, CO₂).

options.label: B
options.text: Covalent bonds form only between metals.

options.label: C
options.text: Covalent bonds require transfer of electrons, so atoms must be different.

options.label: D
options.text: Only ionic bonds can form between different atoms.

questions.key_concept: Covalent bonds form between non-metals, same or different.

questions.question_text: What is the covalency of carbon in methane (CH₄)?
questions.key_concept: Carbon shares 4 electron pairs, so covalency = 4.

questions.question_text: How does a single covalent bond differ from a double covalent bond in terms of electron sharing?

options.label: A
options.text: Single bond: sharing of 1 electron pair. Double bond: sharing of 2 electron pairs.

options.label: B
options.text: Single bond: sharing of 2 electron pairs. Double bond: sharing of 4 electron pairs.

options.label: C
options.text: Both involve sharing of 1 electron pair, but the distance differs.

options.label: D
options.text: Single bond is ionic; double bond is covalent.

questions.key_concept: Number of shared electron pairs defines bond order.

questions.question_text: Why do non-metal atoms usually form covalent bonds rather than ionic bonds when combining with each other?

options.label: A
options.text: Both have high electronegativity and tend to gain electrons; neither tends to lose electrons easily. Sharing electrons allows both to attain octet.

options.label: B
options.text: Non-metals have low ionization energy and readily lose electrons.

options.label: C
options.text: Covalent bonds are weaker, so they form easily.

options.label: D
options.text: Ionic bonds require metals, which are not present.

questions.key_concept: High IE and EA of non-metals favor sharing over transfer.

concepts.concept_name: Formation of Specific Covalent Molecules (H₂, Cl₂, N₂, HCl, H₂O, NH₃, CH₄, CCl₄)

questions.question_text: How many shared electron pairs are there in a chlorine molecule (Cl₂)?
questions.key_concept: Cl-Cl single bond: one shared pair.

questions.question_text: Which of the following molecules has a double covalent bond?

options.label: A
options.text: H₂

options.label: B
options.text: O₂

options.label: C
options.text: N₂

options.label: D
options.text: HCl

questions.key_concept: O=O double bond.

questions.question_text: A student draws the electron dot structure for ammonia (NH₃) with nitrogen having only 6 electrons in its valence shell. What is missing?

options.label: A
options.text: Nitrogen should have a lone pair of electrons in addition to the three bonds, making its total valence electrons 8 (octet).

options.label: B
options.text: Nitrogen should form a double bond with one hydrogen.

options.label: C
options.text: Hydrogen should have 8 electrons.

options.label: D
options.text: There should be no lone pair on nitrogen.

questions.key_concept: N has 5 valence e-. In NH₃, it forms 3 bonds (uses 3 e-) and retains one lone pair (2 e-), total 8.

questions.question_text: How many single covalent bonds are present in a molecule of methane (CH₄)?
questions.key_concept: Carbon forms four single bonds with four hydrogen atoms.

questions.question_text: How does the bonding in hydrogen chloride (HCl) differ from that in chlorine (Cl₂) in terms of electron pair distribution?

options.label: A
options.text: In HCl, the shared pair is closer to Cl (polar covalent). In Cl₂, the shared pair is equally distributed (non-polar covalent).

options.label: B
options.text: HCl is ionic; Cl₂ is covalent.

options.label: C
options.text: Both are ionic bonds.

options.label: D
options.text: Both have equally shared electron pairs.

questions.key_concept: Polar vs. non-polar covalent bonds.

questions.question_text: Why does carbon form four covalent bonds in compounds like CH₄ and CCl₄?

options.label: A
options.text: Carbon has 4 valence electrons; it needs 4 more to complete its octet, so it shares 4 electron pairs.

options.label: B
options.text: Carbon has 6 valence electrons and needs to lose 2.

options.label: C
options.text: Carbon can only form double bonds.

options.label: D
options.text: Carbon is a metal, so it loses 4 electrons.

questions.key_concept: Tetravalency of carbon due to its electronic configuration (2,4).

questions.question_text: What is a non-polar covalent bond?

options.label: A
options.text: A bond where electrons are transferred completely.

options.label: B
options.text: A bond where shared electrons are equally distributed between identical atoms.

options.label: C
options.text: A bond between a metal and a non-metal.

options.label: D
options.text: A bond that ionizes in water.

questions.key_concept: Non-polar: equal sharing, usually between identical atoms.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a polar covalent molecule?

options.label: A
options.text: H₂

options.label: B
options.text: Cl₂

options.label: C
options.text: HCl

options.label: D
options.text: CH₄

questions.key_concept: HCl has different electronegativities, leading to polar bond.

questions.question_text: A student says that CCl₄ is a polar molecule because C-Cl bonds are polar. Why is the molecule as a whole considered non-polar?

options.label: A
options.text: The polar C-Cl bonds are symmetrically arranged (tetrahedral), canceling out the dipole moments, making the molecule non-polar.

options.label: B
options.text: Carbon and chlorine have the same electronegativity.

options.label: C
options.text: CCl₄ ionizes completely in water, so it's ionic, not polar.

options.label: D
options.text: All covalent molecules are non-polar.

questions.key_concept: Symmetry can make a molecule with polar bonds non-polar overall.

questions.question_text: What causes a covalent bond to be polar?

options.label: A
options.text: Difference in electronegativity between the bonded atoms.

options.label: B
options.text: The presence of a metal atom.

options.label: C
options.text: The bond being a double or triple bond.

options.label: D
options.text: The molecule being linear in shape.

questions.key_concept: Unequal sharing due to electronegativity difference.

questions.question_text: How do polar and non-polar covalent compounds differ in their interaction with water?

options.label: A
options.text: Polar covalent compounds often dissolve in water due to dipole interactions; non-polar compounds generally do not.

options.label: B
options.text: Non-polar compounds dissolve easily in water; polar compounds do not.

options.label: C
options.text: Both dissolve equally well.

options.label: D
options.text: Neither type dissolves in water; only ionic compounds do.

questions.key_concept: Like dissolves like: polar solvents dissolve polar solutes.

questions.question_text: Why does HCl conduct electricity in aqueous solution while Cl₂ gas does not?

options.label: A
options.text: HCl is a polar covalent molecule that ionizes in water to form H⁺ and Cl⁻ ions, which conduct electricity. Cl₂ is non-polar and does not ionize.

options.label: B
options.text: HCl is ionic in the solid state.

options.label: C
options.text: Cl₂ ionizes in water to form Cl⁻ ions.

options.label: D
options.text: Both conduct electricity equally well.

questions.key_concept: Polar covalent molecules can dissociate into ions in water.

concepts.concept_name: Comparison of Electrovalent and Covalent Compounds

questions.question_text: Which type of compounds generally have high melting and boiling points?

options.label: A
options.text: Electrovalent (Ionic) compounds

options.label: B
options.text: Covalent compounds

options.label: C
options.text: Both have similar melting points.

options.label: D
options.text: Neither have defined melting points.

questions.key_concept: Ionic compounds have strong electrostatic forces, requiring high heat to break.

questions.question_text: Which type of compounds are usually soluble in water?

options.label: A
options.text: Electrovalent compounds

options.label: B
options.text: Covalent compounds

options.label: C
options.text: Both are equally soluble.

options.label: D
options.text: Neither is soluble.

questions.key_concept: Many ionic compounds dissolve in polar solvents like water.

questions.question_text: A student states that covalent compounds never conduct electricity. Under what condition might this be false?

options.label: A
options.text: When dissolved in water, some polar covalent compounds (like HCl) ionize and conduct electricity.

options.label: B
options.text: In the solid state, all covalent compounds conduct.

options.label: C
options.text: When melted, all covalent compounds conduct.

options.label: D
options.text: Covalent compounds always conduct better than ionic compounds.

questions.key_concept: Polar covalent compounds can conduct in aqueous solution due to ionization.

questions.question_text: A solid is crystalline, hard, has a high melting point, and is soluble in water. What type of bonding is it most likely to have?

options.label: A
options.text: Electrovalent (Ionic) bonding

options.label: B
options.text: Covalent bonding

options.label: C
options.text: Metallic bonding

options.label: D
options.text: Hydrogen bonding

questions.key_concept: These are typical properties of ionic compounds.

questions.question_text: How do the physical states of typical ionic and covalent compounds at room temperature often differ?

options.label: A
options.text: Ionic compounds are usually solids; covalent compounds can be solids, liquids, or gases.

options.label: B
options.text: Ionic compounds are gases; covalent compounds are solids.

options.label: C
options.text: Both are always solids.

options.label: D
options.text: Both are always gases.

questions.key_concept: Ionic compounds form crystalline solids due to strong lattice forces. Covalent molecules have weaker intermolecular forces, allowing various states.

questions.question_text: Why are electrovalent compounds brittle, whereas covalent compounds are not necessarily so?

options.label: A
options.text: In ionic solids, a shift in layers brings like charges adjacent, causing repulsion and fracture. Covalent networks or molecules do not necessarily have this charge-based repulsion.

options.label: B
options.text: Ionic compounds are soft and malleable.

options.label: C
options.text: Covalent compounds are always brittle.

options.label: D
options.text: Brittleness is unrelated to bond type.

questions.key_concept: Brittleness of ionic solids is due to the nature of the ionic lattice.
